search.slidetext: v(d)j recombination antigen receptor development in adaptive immune cells

cells of the adaptive immune system b and t cells, also referred to as lymphocytes, are cells of the adaptive immune system. these cells carry antigen receptors for unique epitopes that are crucial to imparting specificity to immune responses. they differ from innate immune cells which have pre-formed receptors which recognise common epitopes, referred to as damps and pamps: danger associated molecular patterns (damps) pathogen associated molecular patterns (pamps) a comparison of b and t cells is shown in the table below: b cells t cells progenitor common lymphoid progenitor common lymphoid progenitor site of maturation bone marrow thymus antigen receptor b cell receptor (bcr) antibody t cell receptor (tcr) major types naive b cell plasma cell memory b cell cd4+ t cell cd8+ t cell
function of antibodies function of antibodies: neutralisation b cell pathogen
macrophage function of antibodies: opsonisation
function of antibodies: complement activation b cell c1 pathogen
function of antibodies: imparting specificity eosinophil
function of tcrs function of tcrs: direct (cd8+ t cell) epithelial cells mhc i cd8+ t cell t cell tcr
macrophage function of tcrs: indirect (cd4+ t cell) mhc ii cd4+ t cell

b cells produce antibodies which have numerous functions including marking cells for opsonisation by phagocytes, neutralisation, acting as a starting point for the complement cascade, and imparting specificity to innate immune cells. t cell surface receptor (tcr), work in direct and indirect ways. tcrs on cd8+ t cells recognise damage or infected cells and can induce cell death. tcrs on cd4+ t cells interact with mhc ii presenting cells and influence their activity continue continue continue continue continue continue incorrect that is incorrect. please try again or continue to review answer. try again try again try again try again try again try again continue continue continue continue continue continue incorrect you did not select the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct that's right! you selected the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue select all which are functions of antibodies: (hint: there are 4 correct answers) opsonisation opsonisation opsonisation opsonisation opsonisation opsonisation neutralisation neutralisation neutralisation neutralisation neutralisation neutralisation complement activation complement activation complement activation complement activation complement activation complement activation imparting specificity imparting specificity imparting specificity imparting specificity imparting specificity imparting specificity cytotoxic lymphocyte receptor cytotoxic lymphocyte receptor cytotoxic lymphocyte receptor cytotoxic lymphocyte receptor cytotoxic lymphocyte receptor cytotoxic lymphocyte receptor interacts with mhc ii presenting cells interacts with mhc ii presenting cells interacts with mhc ii presenting cells interacts with mhc ii presenting cells interacts with mhc ii presenting cells interacts with mhc ii presenting cells

development of antigen receptor diversity vdj recombination is a form dna recombination that occurs in lymphocytes. highly controlled process of selecting and joining non-contiguous unique gene segments at random, to generate a unique variable domain sequence and receptor antigen recognition site. diversity is generated by two main mechanisms: combinatorial diversity junctional diversity vdj recombination allows for diversity to be generated from a small amount of genetic material. to put this into perspective: human genome contains ~25,000 genes antibody diversity potential is ~ 1 trillion required number of receptor genes without vdj recombination: 1 million heavy chains and 1 million light chains this process of increasing the repertoire of proteins is different to mechanisms such as mrna splicing and protein modification, which do not edit the dna.

number of gene segments for each receptor chain adapted from fig 4.13 of abbas, a. k., et al. (2019). basic immunology: functions and disorders of the immune system, elsevierevier. b cell t cell heavy chain light chain (kappa) light chain (lambda) alpha chain beta chain variable segments 45 35 30 45 48 diversity segments 23 0 0 0 2 joining segments 6 5 4 50 12 # of v(d)j combinations 6210 175 120 2250 1152 # of chain combinations 1,831,950 2,592,000

junctional diversity junctional diversity arises through the joining of gene segments. enzymes are responsible for cutting and combining the gene segments together, but the process is variable. depending on how the genes are cut and pasted, even if two lymphocytes choose the same v, d, j segments, the sequence of the combined vdj will be different in each lymphocyte.

vdj recombination: overview vdj recombination is a multi-step process that is intertwined with the development of lymphocytes. successful recombination is required for lymphocyte development. it is highly coordinated by numerous enzyme complexes. vdj recombination is an ordered process on the segment level: d to j recombination occurs first v to dj recombination follows the process can be broken down into 4 main steps: synapsis cleavage hairpin opening and end processing joining

legend vdj recombination: steps 1 and 2 rag1/2 complex flanking sequence signal joint hairpins v segment d segment j segment v flanking sequence d flanking sequence j flanking sequence constant domain
vdj recombination: step 3
vdj recombination: step 4 p nucleotides p nucleotides n nucleotides n nucleotides
vdj recombination: ordering legend v segment d segment j segment v flanking sequence d flanking sequence j flanking sequence constant domain new sequence

vdj recombination is a multi-step process which is required for lymphocyte development and function. it is the process by which receptor diversity is generated. it is achieved via irreversible dna in the case of v to dj rearrangement in b cells being unsuccessful, v to dj rearrangement of the other heavy chain loci can occur. d to j rearrangement of the two heavy chain loci in the b cell occurs at the same time. continue continue continue continue continue continue incorrect that is incorrect. please try again or continue to review answer. try again try again try again try again try again try again continue continue continue continue continue continue incorrect you did not select the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct that's right! you selected the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue if heavy chain v-dj rearrangement in a b cell is unsuccessful, what mechanism allows for the antigen receptor and cell to be salvaged? repeated rearrangement repeated rearrangement repeated rearrangement repeated rearrangement repeated rearrangement repeated rearrangement v-dj rearrangement of other heavy chain loci v-dj rearrangement of other heavy chain loci v-dj rearrangement of other heavy chain loci v-dj rearrangement of other heavy chain loci v-dj rearrangement of other heavy chain loci v-dj rearrangement of other heavy chain loci no mechanism is available no mechanism is available no mechanism is available no mechanism is available no mechanism is available no mechanism is available mrna editing mrna editing mrna editing mrna editing mrna editing mrna editing protein modification protein modification protein modification protein modification protein modification protein modification

summary specificity of b and t cells is imparted by their unique antigen receptor. the structures of the bcr/antibody and tcr are analogous, made up of a protein heterodimer. each chain is composed of variable and constant domains: variable domains contribute to the antigen recognition site. constant domains are important for cell anchorage and interacting with cell surface proteins. heavy/beta variable domains are made up of v, d, j segments, while light/alpha variable domains are made up of v and j segments. vdj recombination is the ordered process which generates unique antigen receptor dna sequences and intertwined with lymphocyte development. diversity is generated through combination of gene segments (combinatorial), and how they are joined to one another (junctional). many rearrangements are unsuccessful but the lymphocytes have mechanisms to salvage non-functional sequences, allowing them to continue to try and develop a functioning receptor.
